expanded_description: This section explores the three key properties that characterize any sound: pitch (determined by frequency), loudness (determined by amplitude), and quality or timbre (determined by the complex mixture of frequencies that gives each sound its unique identity). Students will learn how these properties combine to create the rich variety of sounds we hear every day.

core_concept.principle: Every sound we hear can be described by three properties: pitch (how high or low it is), loudness (how strong or weak it is), and quality (what makes it sound like a violin versus a flute versus a voice). These correspond to the physical wave properties of frequency, amplitude, and waveform shape.
core_concept.explanation: Imagine hearing a piano and a guitar play the same note at the same volume. You can instantly tell which is which—that's quality. The note itself has a specific pitch (frequency) and loudness (amplitude), but the instrument's unique mixture of overtones creates its characteristic sound. Together, these three properties make every sound distinct.

image.alt: Diagram showing three sound waves: one with high frequency (high pitch), one with large amplitude (loud), and two different wave shapes (different quality) for same pitch and loudness
image.caption: Pitch (frequency), loudness (amplitude), and quality (waveform) describe any sound

sections.section_title: Pitch: The Highness or Lowness of Sound
sections.introduction: When we describe a sound as high or low, we're talking about its pitch. From the deepest bass note to the highest whistle, pitch is one of the most noticeable characteristics of sound.

key_concept.definition: Pitch is our perceptual response to the frequency of a sound wave. Higher frequency waves are perceived as higher pitch; lower frequency waves as lower pitch.
key_concept.context: Frequency is measured in hertz (Hz)—the number of vibrations per second. A sound at 440 Hz (orchestra's A) vibrates 440 times every second.

principles.statement: The pitch you hear depends directly on the frequency of the sound wave. Double the frequency, and you perceive a pitch one octave higher.
principles.application: Musical notes are organized by frequency. Each octave represents a doubling of frequency.
principles.example: Middle C on a piano is about 262 Hz. The C one octave higher is 524 Hz. The C one octave lower is 131 Hz.
principles.analogy: Think of a wheel spinning: faster spin (higher frequency) = higher pitch; slower spin = lower pitch.

principles.statement: Humans can typically hear frequencies from about 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (20 kHz), though this range shrinks with age.
principles.application: Sounds below 20 Hz (infrasound) are felt more than heard; sounds above 20 kHz (ultrasound) are inaudible to humans.
principles.example: A bass drum might produce frequencies around 50 Hz; a piccolo can reach several kHz; a dog whistle at 25 kHz is silent to humans but audible to dogs.

characteristics: Long wavelengths (meters to tens of meters)
Often felt as much as heard

examples.explanation: Produces low frequencies that provide rhythmic and harmonic foundation.
Low-frequency rumbling that can travel long distances.
Typically lower pitch than female voice due to longer vocal cords.

characteristics: Human ear most sensitive in this range

examples.explanation: Most speech sounds fall in this range, which is why we hear them well.
Covers mid to high frequencies depending on string and position.
Typically higher pitch than male voice.
Contains many high frequencies that give it shimmer.
Many bird calls contain high-frequency components.
Audiologists test high-frequency hearing with tones around 8-12 kHz.

image.alt: Diagram showing waves of different frequencies: low frequency (widely spaced) labeled low pitch, high frequency (closely spaced) labeled high pitch
image.caption: Higher frequency waves (closer together) produce higher pitch

sections.introduction: Some sounds are barely perceptible whispers; others can be painfully loud. This property—loudness—depends on the energy carried by the sound wave.

key_concept.definition: Loudness is our perceptual response to the amplitude (intensity) of a sound wave. Larger amplitude waves are perceived as louder; smaller amplitude as softer.
key_concept.context: Amplitude corresponds to the amount of pressure variation in the wave—how much air molecules are compressed in compressions and spread in rarefactions.

principles.statement: The greater the amplitude of a sound wave, the more energy it carries, and the louder we perceive it.
principles.application: Doubling the amplitude increases energy by a factor of 4, but our ears perceive this as a moderate increase in loudness (not 4× louder).
principles.example: A whisper has tiny amplitude; a shout has much larger amplitude—maybe 1000× more energy!
principles.analogy: Think of pushing someone on a swing: small pushes (small amplitude) = gentle motion; big pushes (large amplitude) = big motion.

principles.statement: Loudness is measured in decibels (dB), a logarithmic scale that matches how our ears perceive sound intensity.
principles.application: Every 10 dB increase represents a 10× increase in sound intensity, but our ears perceive it as roughly twice as loud.
principles.example: 60 dB (normal conversation) to 70 dB is 10× more intense but sounds about twice as loud. 60 dB to 80 dB is 100× more intense!

classifications.value: Everyday sounds and their approximate dB levels
characteristics: 0 dB: Threshold of hearing (faintest detectable sound)
40 dB: Quiet library, soft background music
80 dB: Busy street, alarm clock at 1 m
100 dB: Subway train, power mower, motorcycle
120 dB: Rock concert, thunderclap, threshold of pain
140 dB: Jet engine at close range, gunshot

examples.explanation: Prolonged exposure above 85 dB can cause hearing damage. Concerts often exceed 100 dB—safe for short periods only.
A whisper (~30 dB) has about 1/1000th the intensity of normal conversation (~60 dB).

image.alt: Vertical decibel scale from 0 dB to 140 dB with pictures of common sounds at each level
image.caption: The decibel scale matches how we perceive loudness—each 10 dB step sounds about twice as loud

sections.note: The decibel scale is logarithmic because our ears respond logarithmically to intensity—we can hear from the faintest pin drop to a jet engine, a range of over a trillion times in intensity!

sections.introduction: A flute and a violin playing the same note at the same volume still sound completely different. That difference is quality, or timbre—the most complex of sound's properties.

key_concept.definition: Quality (timbre) is the characteristic that allows us to distinguish between different sources producing the same pitch and loudness. It is determined by the mixture of frequencies present in a sound—the fundamental frequency plus its overtones.
key_concept.context: Most sounds are not pure tones (single frequencies). They're complex waves containing multiple frequencies that give each sound its unique "color" or "texture."

principles.statement: When an object vibrates, it typically vibrates at multiple frequencies simultaneously. The lowest frequency is the fundamental (determining pitch); higher frequencies are overtones (or harmonics).
principles.application: The relative strength of different overtones creates the characteristic sound of each instrument or voice.
principles.example: A violin and a flute both playing A440 (440 Hz) have the same fundamental. But the violin has strong overtones at 880 Hz, 1320 Hz, etc., while the flute's overtones have different relative strengths—that's why they sound different.
principles.analogy: Think of a recipe: the fundamental is the main ingredient (like flour), but overtones are the spices—they make cookies taste different even with the same flour base.

principles.statement: The combination of fundamental and overtones creates a complex waveform with a unique shape. Pure tones (like a tuning fork) have simple sine wave shapes; complex sounds have intricate, repeating patterns.
principles.application: The waveform shape is the physical representation of timbre. Different instruments have characteristic waveform shapes.
principles.example: A tuning fork produces a sine wave (smooth, pure). A clarinet produces a waveform closer to a square wave; a violin produces a sawtooth-like wave.

characteristics: Example: tuning fork, electronic tone generator

examples.explanation: Produces nearly pure sine wave—used for tuning instruments because pitch is clear.
Pure tones used to test hearing at specific frequencies.
Complex waveform with many overtones—hammer striking string creates rich sound.
Extremely complex with many overtones—vocal tract shapes the sound.
Bowed string produces complex waveform with strong overtones.

image.alt: Comparison of waveforms: sine wave (pure tone), square wave, sawtooth wave, and complex wave from an instrument, all same frequency
image.caption: Different waveforms produce different timbres—same pitch, different sound quality

worked_examples.title: Identifying Sound Properties
worked_examples.problem: You hear a trumpet and a flute playing the same note at the same volume. What property allows you to tell them apart? What physical characteristic of the sound wave causes this?

step_by_step.explanation: Same note means same fundamental frequency → same pitch.
Same volume means similar amplitude → same loudness.
You can still tell them apart because of quality/timbre.
Timbre is caused by different mixtures of overtones (harmonic content).

worked_examples.final_answer: The property is quality (timbre), caused by different mixtures of overtones creating different waveform shapes.

sections.section_title: How Pitch, Loudness, and Quality Combine
sections.introduction: In real-world sounds, these three properties work together to create everything we hear—from a single note to a symphony orchestra.

principles.statement: Pitch, loudness, and quality can vary independently. You can change one without affecting the others.
principles.application: This is why a violin can play high or low notes (different pitch) loudly or softly (different loudness) while still sounding like a violin (same quality).
principles.example: A singer can sing the same note (same pitch) loudly or softly (different loudness) and still sound like themselves (same quality).

principles.statement: Scientists and audio engineers use spectrum analyzers to visualize the frequency content of sounds—showing the fundamental and all overtones.
principles.application: This helps in sound design, audio processing, and understanding what makes sounds unique.
principles.example: A spectrum of a violin note shows peaks at the fundamental and many harmonic frequencies; a flute shows a different pattern of peaks.

image.alt: Frequency spectrum graphs showing fundamental and overtones for violin and flute playing same note
image.caption: Spectrum analysis reveals the harmonic content that creates each instrument's unique timbre

sections.introduction: Understanding pitch, loudness, and quality is essential in music, medicine, communication, and many other fields.

categories.description: Musicians and engineers manipulate these properties constantly.

examples.explanation: Boost or cut specific frequency ranges to change timbre—making a sound brighter (boost high frequencies) or warmer (boost low frequencies).
Adjusts amplitude—changes loudness without affecting pitch or quality (ideally).
Electronic instruments that create sounds by combining waveforms with controlled frequencies and amplitudes.
Engineers balance pitch, loudness, and quality of multiple tracks to create a pleasing final mix.

categories.description: Speech recognition and synthesis depend on understanding these properties.

examples.explanation: Each person's voice has unique timbre—that's how you recognize friends on the phone.
Pitch and loudness convey emotion—excitement (higher pitch, louder), calm (lower pitch, softer).
In tonal languages (like Mandarin), pitch changes change word meanings.

categories.description: Doctors listen to body sounds for diagnosis.

examples.explanation: Pitch, loudness, and quality of heartbeats reveal valve function and potential problems.
Wheezing (high pitch) indicates narrowed airways; crackles indicate fluid.
Using a stethoscope to listen to internal body sounds—requires recognizing normal vs abnormal timbre.

categories.description: Managing unwanted sound requires understanding its properties.

examples.explanation: Different frequencies require different barrier designs—low frequencies (long wavelengths) are harder to block.
Earplugs and earmuffs reduce loudness, especially at damaging high frequencies.
Creates waves to destructively interfere with incoming noise—works best for constant low-frequency sounds.

image.alt: Collage showing audio mixing board, doctor with stethoscope, voice waveform, and noise-canceling headphones
image.caption: Understanding sound properties helps in music, medicine, communication, and noise control

sections.section_title: Simple Experiments to Explore Sound Properties
sections.introduction: You can investigate pitch, loudness, and quality with simple materials.

process_flow.description: Use several bottles filled with different amounts of water. Blow across the tops.
process_flow.mechanism: More water = shorter air column = higher pitch. Less water = longer air column = lower pitch.
process_flow.result: You can create a scale of notes by adjusting water levels.
applications: Relates air column length to pitch

process_flow.description: Use a rubber band stretched across a box. Pluck it gently, then harder.
process_flow.mechanism: Gentle pluck = small amplitude = soft sound. Hard pluck = large amplitude = loud sound.
process_flow.result: Pitch stays same (same rubber band) but loudness changes with force.
applications: Shows amplitude affects loudness, not pitch

process_flow.description: Collect different objects that can produce sound: ruler on table edge, rubber band, spoon on glass, etc.
process_flow.mechanism: Make sounds with each, trying to match pitch and loudness roughly.
process_flow.result: Each object has unique sound even at same pitch and loudness—different timbre.
applications: Demonstrates that quality depends on object

process_flow.description: Use a smartphone with an oscilloscope app or sound analysis app.
process_flow.mechanism: Make sounds into the phone's microphone and watch the waveform.
process_flow.result: Different sounds show different waveform patterns—pure tones show sine waves; complex sounds show irregular patterns.
applications: See the physical representation of timbre

sections.introduction: Apply your understanding of sound properties.

worked_examples.title: Problem 1: Identifying Properties
worked_examples.problem: Identify whether each describes pitch, loudness, or quality: a) A note sounds higher than another; b) A trumpet sounds different from a trombone playing same note; c) A sound is barely audible; d) A voice sounds like your mother's.

step_by_step.explanation: a) Higher/lower refers to pitch (frequency). b) Different instruments same note = quality/timbre. c) Barely audible refers to loudness (amplitude). d) Recognizing a voice = quality/timbre.

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Pitch, b) Quality, c) Loudness, d) Quality

worked_examples.title: Problem 2: Pitch and Frequency
worked_examples.problem: A sound wave has frequency 200 Hz. Another has frequency 800 Hz. Which has higher pitch? How many times higher is the frequency?

step_by_step.explanation: 800 Hz > 200 Hz, so second sound has higher pitch.

worked_examples.final_answer: The 800 Hz sound has higher pitch, with 4 times the frequency.

worked_examples.title: Problem 3: Loudness and Amplitude
worked_examples.problem: Sound A has twice the amplitude of Sound B. How do their energies compare? How would their loudness compare perceptually?

step_by_step.explanation: Energy ∝ amplitude², so twice amplitude = 4× energy.
Our ears perceive this as louder, but not 4× louder—maybe 1.5-2× louder subjectively.

worked_examples.final_answer: Sound A has 4 times more energy than Sound B, and sounds noticeably louder.

worked_examples.title: Problem 4: Understanding Timbre
worked_examples.problem: A guitar and a piano both play the same note at the same volume. Why do they sound different?

step_by_step.explanation: Same note means same fundamental frequency.
Different instruments produce different mixtures of overtones (harmonics).

worked_examples.final_answer: They sound different because they produce different overtones (harmonic content), which creates different timbre/quality.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Timbre is determined by overtone mixture.

worked_examples.title: Problem 5: Decibel Scale
worked_examples.problem: Normal conversation is about 60 dB. A subway train is about 100 dB. How many times more intense is the subway train sound?

step_by_step.explanation: 100 dB - 60 dB = 40 dB difference = 4 steps of 10 dB.

worked_examples.final_answer: The subway train sound is 10,000 times more intense than normal conversation.

worked_examples.title: Problem 6: Combined Properties
worked_examples.problem: Describe how you could change the pitch, loudness, and quality of a guitar sound.

step_by_step.explanation: Press string at different frets (changes vibrating length) → changes frequency.
Pluck harder or softer → changes amplitude.
Pluck closer to bridge (brighter) or closer to neck (warmer), use different picking technique, or use effects.

worked_examples.final_answer: Pitch: change fret position; Loudness: change plucking force; Quality: change plucking position/technique.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Independence and control of sound properties.

sections.introduction: Here are frequent misunderstandings about sound properties.

principles.principle: Misconception: Loudness and pitch are the same
principles.statement: Students often confuse loud (amplitude) with high pitch (frequency).
principles.application: They're completely independent—you can have loud low notes (bass drum) and soft high notes (piccolo).
principles.example: Thunder is loud but low pitch; a cricket chirp is soft but high pitch.

principles.principle: Misconception: All sounds have a single frequency
principles.statement: Many think every sound is a pure tone like a tuning fork.
principles.application: Most sounds are complex mixtures of many frequencies. Pure tones are rare in nature.
principles.example: Even a single note on a piano contains a fundamental plus many overtones.

principles.statement: Some think shouting makes your voice reach someone sooner.
principles.application: Loudness affects energy, not speed. All sound at same temperature travels same speed regardless of loudness.
principles.example: A whisper and a shout both travel at ~340 m/s in air.

principles.principle: Misconception: High pitch sounds are always loud
principles.statement: Students may associate high pitch with loudness because sirens are both high and loud.
principles.application: Pitch and loudness are independent. High notes can be soft; low notes can be loud.
principles.example: A flute can play very softly at high pitch; a bass drum is loud at low pitch.

principles.principle: Misconception: Timbre is just "tone color" and not physically measurable
principles.statement: Some think quality is subjective and can't be measured.
principles.application: Timbre is physically measurable as the spectrum of frequencies (overtones) present in a sound.
principles.example: Spectrum analyzers show exact frequency content—different instruments have different spectral patterns.

summary: Every sound is characterized by three properties: pitch, loudness, and quality. Pitch is determined by frequency—higher frequency = higher pitch. Humans hear roughly 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Loudness is determined by amplitude—larger amplitude = louder sound, measured in decibels (dB) on a logarithmic scale. Every 10 dB increase represents 10× more intensity. Quality (timbre) is what makes sounds with the same pitch and loudness sound different—it's determined by the mixture of overtones (harmonics) present. Most sounds are complex tones containing a fundamental frequency (which determines pitch) plus higher-frequency overtones whose relative strengths create characteristic waveforms. These three properties can vary independently, allowing infinite variety in sound. Understanding them explains how we recognize voices and instruments, how audio engineers shape sound, and how doctors diagnose through listening. This foundation prepares us for exploring the human ear in the next section—how we perceive these properties.
